entry.title: Displaying Hierarchical Data in a Grid (WPF)
entry.content:
I stumbled upon a question on StackOverflow. The essence of the question was binding a hierarchical data to a grid component. I found this question interesting and did a quick search. There were many examples on how to display hierarchical data in trees or nested grids but I did not found an example on putting it in a single grid. So I decided to create mine.

I decided to up the difficulty by not writing any custom code in pages or windows and keep everything in MVVM+XAML way. I started by creating a sample hierarchical data parallel to the question. There are sellers and these sellers have items in their stocks. For simplicity I selected primary keys for both suppliers and items to be their names. Items naturally have different prices in different suppliers and these should be editable. To up the challenge a little further letâ€™s assume not all the suppliers have the same items. So;

Supplier1: Item1,Item2,Item3
Supplier2: Item2,Item3
Supplier3: Item1,Item3,Item4

The question stated that new suppliers to be added on runtime.

The next thing is to keep list of suppliers. We want this list to be a singleton and easily accessible. So I used MVVM Light Toolkit which has a handy Locator class. I decided to create random data to experiment. Of course normally this is not the way to go, you want well defined mocks for unit testing.

Now we have our data ready. Turning back to our previous example what we need to do now is to show this data in a grid.

Supplier1: Item1,Item2,Item3
Supplier2: Item2,Item3
Supplier3: Item1,Item3,Item4

into

Supplier1 Supplier2 Supplier3
Item1 50 48
Item2 10 11
Item3 20 9 15
Item4 40

The next problem is representing the empty slots in the grid. A supplier does not know what other suppliers have in their inventories. One way to solve this problem is, to pass the supplier a list of all possible item names and ask for it to return a list of items where the missing item slots simply left blank. Then we can select the proper data templates in XAML for these items. A textbox to edit the price and an empty cell for the missing item. But blanks are harder to create data triggers on and I preferred to rely on data types. So I created a class ItemViewModelFake: ItemViewModel just to give it a different data type.

In WPF you canâ€™t pass data to a binding property. One way to overcome this problem is to use converters. But since the task here is very simple I relied on the Locater and pulled the data from the view model.

The order of items is handled by the MainViewModel and the supplier class respects this order. Now we can select the proper templates in XAML;

To create a proper grid, we need row and column headers. We have all the real suppliers, but to create the rowheader column where we display the distinct item names, we need a new supplier which has all the items.

The hard work is done. Now we need to display this data in a grid like manner. Since we still do not have a tabular data we canâ€™t use a regular datagrid. But we can mimic one with the help of UniformGrid and ItemsControl. The complete XAML now looks like this;

One last thing to do is to handle the creation of suppliers. Our view uses a custom list of suppliers and items. Therefor we need to call the RaisePropertyChanged() events manually. But since event handling and list creation is done in different view models, we need a method to pass the required messages between them. Luckily MVVM Light offers such a mechanism.

We are done! The final screenshots are below. You may check the complete solution on GitHub. This is a basic proof of concept with lots of room for improvement. Like scrolling and sorting the grid etc. I will try to convert this code to use a DataGrid later on.

entry.title: One way to catch unclosed SQL connections in .NET
entry.content:
There are many approaches to prevent and deal with SQL connection leaks with the emphasis on prevention. But there are also the cases where you may want to catch and report them on runtime and pinpoint their origin. This is one approach to do so.

NumberOfReclaimedConnections performance counter in ADO.Net gives you the number of connections reclaimed by the garbage collector. Although this tells you that there are leaks in the code it doesnâ€™t help you in finding them. One way to pinpoint the origin of the leeks is writing your own wrapper around the SQL connection and handling it yourself.
First job is to catch these leeks. Letâ€™s have a very simple wrapper:

When you want to clean things up in code, you implement the IDisposable interface and do it in Dispose() method. But there is a special Finalize method which is called when the GC collects an object. This is a great place for our purpose. Here we can know if the connection has not been closed and since this is the last step in objects life cycle we can be sure that this is a leaked connection and log it. In c# Finalizer is implemented as ~ClassName(){}

Now we can know when there is a leak. But we still need to find where it originates. Having a StackTrace data will give us everything we need. The problem is, this is happening in garbage collector and our object is not connected to anything. But we can get the StackTrace on constructor, store it and if we catch a leek we can log it. Since getting the stack trace data is very expensive you may want to make it conditional. Anything that works for you; configuration file, environment variables, build configuration etc..

And thatâ€™s it! Now you can directly go to the method that opens the connection and debug it. You may choose to handle the error in any way that suits you. Write to event log, use your regular logging methods, throw an exception etc.
entry.summary: There are many approaches to prevent and deal with SQL connection leaks with the emphasis on prevention. But there are also the cases where you may want to catch and report them on runtime and pinpoint their origin. This is one approach to do so.
